greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = greatest ludic number (A003309) that divides n.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10001
Index entries for sequences generated by sieves
example: a(19) = 1 as 19 is not a ludic number, but it is a prime, thus only ludic number that divides it is the very first one A003309(1) = 1.
a(589) = 1 also as 589 = 19*31 and both 19 and 31 are in A192505.
program: (define (A276440 n) (let loop ((k 1) (mt 1)) (let ((t (A003309 k))) (cond ((> t n) mt) ((zero? (modulo n t)) (loop (+ 1 k) t)) (else (loop (+ 1 k) mt))))))
xref: Differs from A006530 for the first time at n=19.
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Sep 11 2016
